docs.snippet: Seth MacFarlane, the creator of ''Family Guy'' on Fox, has joined AdSense, a Google network that places ads on Web sites, to create original, animated short videos. The agreement was announced yesterday by Media Rights Capital, which is underwriti...
docs.lead_paragraph: Seth MacFarlane, the creator of ''Family Guy'' on Fox, has joined AdSense, a Google network that places ads on Web sites, to create original, animated short videos. The agreement was announced yesterday by Media Rights Capital, which is underwriting the production. Mr. MacFarlane's videos will be accessible through banner and other advertisements as an incentive to Web users to click on those ads.

docs.snippet: A village plots its comeback with the help of a Rocky statue....
docs.lead_paragraph: Everyone loves an underdog, which is why a poor town in the north of Serbia has placed its hopes and dreams in Rocky Balboa. As the story that is proliferating in Google News goes, the village of Zitiste has decided to spark its comeback after years of flooding with the help of a replica of the Rocky statue that stands in Philadelphia.

docs.abstract: By now, everybody, I hope, knows what LOL stands for. Most people probably recognize IMHO, BRB, and AFK. (If you don't know these, you can always Google* them.) Online shorthand like this arose, of course, because it's so hard to type full English words on a cellphone's number keypad. And it's tedious to type the [...]

docs.snippet: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about political contributions by Silicon Valley executives omitted the name of one presidential candidate who recently visited Google’s headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about political contributions by Silicon Valley executives omitted the name of one presidential candidate who recently visited Google’s headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., and erroneously included another candidate. John Edwards spoke there; Barack Obama did not. The article also referred imprecisely to contributions from Google employees to Ron Paul, another candidate. Mr. Paul received $3,550 in employee contributions before he visited on July 13, not after.
